instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2523: What is 820-2523? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.5V_S3: What is 5V_S3? 5V_S3 is an abbreviation of “PP5V_S3” which is a 5 volt power rail present in an S3 state. S3 (Suspend to RAM) is a state where the system saves its context to RAM, a faster but more power-consuming method than S4. The system shuts down most components except for RAM, which remains powered to retain the system state. PM_SLP_S4_L is required for this rail to be present. .
definitions.U7201: What is U7201? U7201 is responsible for the 3.3v and 5v power rails on many devices..
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2523</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> "temporary" short on <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message: This <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2523</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> sometimes turns on but mostly it is dead. Sometimes it turns on but has a black screen. Except for a lot of smokey black dust the board looks fine. I checked power rails and <SIGNAL>PP5_S3</SIGNAL> is missing. After i disconnected the charger it is shortet (0.02V in diode mode) but it is slowly recovering as long as the board is off. It comes back to 0.4V. If i plug the charger back in and disconnect it again it is shorted again. I injected voltage and <CHIP>U7201</CHIP> was getting hot. I replaced it twice but still the same. Also the same happens to <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>. Now i am stuck here...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2523</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> "temporary" short on <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message: That is normal and is just residual charge on the gates of the FETs. I honestly have no idea what this could be as it could be anything. Seeing it is intermittent it could very well be corrosion under something. But is could be anything really, not looking good for this antique.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2523</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> "temporary" short on <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message: ok, thanks. So as the "temporary short" is ok and not the problem here i kept searching and - what else could it be - the <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> enable and <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> are missing... Are there areas on this board (like <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> on the <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>) that i could check?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2523</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> "temporary" short on <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message: No real known issues with this board. If this does intermittent crap like this I doubt it will be worth your time. Probably will end up a no fix and a lot of wasted time.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2523</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> "temporary" short on <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Ok... Thank you for the help
